农企本，720p分辨率+全低效+FXAA，顶着稳定的18-25帧，把本体和DLC的主线通了，支线做了些许。 虽然电脑渣，但此设置下的画面并不太差，BUG很少遇到，优化还行。  作为育碧野心勃勃的一作，虽然遭遇了大BUG，乃至波及了主机玩家群体而导致育碧只能送季票表示歉意，但此作素质还算过硬，依然是一款优秀的刺客信条作品。  （看完小说后，真心喜欢艾丽丝这个角色，育婊的剧本竟然把她搞死了......） ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~        大革命完全革新掉了前两作的操作方式，从自由奔跑到战斗系统再到潜行暗杀，一开始还有些许操作不习惯。本作去掉了无敌的防反系统，不过战斗动作也感觉有些僵硬，敌人稍微多起来就容易招架不住，容易来不及防御或者躲闪子弹，简单地说本作不适合无脑屠城。尤其是在初始阶段，武器不好，扛伤害能力未解锁，突突突很容易挂的。不过后期有了强力武器，杀个五六个还是可以的。但依然没有前作的狂战士能力，所以没事就尽量别硬突。          关于潜行系统，只能说主角终于特么可以控制蹲下了。不过坑爹的育碧在位置判定上做得还是很凑合，时常蹲下找掩体一不小心蹲到敌人眼前。在翻越窗户时偶尔也会直接爬到墙上去。不过好处是被发现后敌人挨个冲过来时，玩家可以在掩体后一个个地用掩体刺杀干掉他们~。另外本作的敌人都跟开了挂似的，被一个人发现其他人瞬间就都发现我了。阳台和房顶的狙击手都跟tm开了鹰眼似的，大老远一露头就发现我了，这作是铁了心的不让玩家硬突啊？          说下画面。虽然电脑渣，但也能感受到此作优秀的图形引擎，大量的生动的npc，一定数量的可进入的房屋，精美的建筑，构成一个庞大而真实的巴黎世界。个人觉得，大革命可以成为本世代游戏画面的旗帜。          新的鹰眼设计得很好，有显示时间和范围的限制，但能力超强，能穿透房屋墙壁看到目标或搜集物品。平衡做得很好。          新的跑酷系统很棒，动作非常流畅连贯，有不少新的跳跃动作和快速刺杀动作。终于可以控制下落而不再直接跳下去了。不过很多跳跃实际看来真是非人类啊，那不是跳跃简直就是飞跃，刺客越来越超人了。              除此之外，本作有许多新元素，如随时自由换装换武器，可以自定义装束，升级技能等（在此提一下，这个技能感觉就是把刺客本来有的许多能力阉割后让玩家慢慢攒技能点再解锁，也就是说育碧似乎有意拖慢游戏节奏）。建议玩家新开存档时优先升级开锁和厚血技能，只做主线的话是无法技能全解锁的，注意酌情解锁技能。新加入的多人合作有些鸡肋，但跟基友开黑很不错。  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~                  关于剧情，衔接叛变的末尾，谢依刺杀了主角的父亲后，主角亚诺被法国圣殿骑士最高大师收养长大。在养父被圣殿骑士内部的人刺杀后展开的复仇之路。在本作中育碧没有太好地塑造人物，以至于亚诺在最后才表达出对刺客信条的理解，可能让玩家以为亚诺一直为复仇战斗。本作故事的矛盾激化源自于圣殿骑士团长德拉赛尔与刺客导师米拉波主持的和平，这与刺客和圣殿骑士之间的千年斗争不符，导致双方内部也矛盾激化。 不过最终亚诺还是杀掉了激进派的领导人并夺回了神器。但代价是失去了青梅竹马的恋人，艾莉丝·德拉赛尔。亚诺与艾莉丝的爱情故事，也以艾莉丝的死画上了句号。不久后亚诺回到了曾驱逐自己的刺客兄弟会，并成为了刺客大师。         整个故事，跟三代有点相似，通关之后都有种莫名的空虚感。体会到了在当时那种大环境下，一个人的力量真的很小，根本改变不了什么。亚诺和康纳一样，虽然都除掉了圣殿骑士的最高首领，但却都没能保护自己想要保护的人。在各自故事的过程中，康纳失去了母亲，父亲，导师，族人；亚诺失去了父亲，养父，两位导师以及心爱的青梅竹马。        艾丽丝之所以急着去追杀杰曼，只是因为她把复仇放在第一，而爱情在第二。但看过小说就知道，艾丽丝在自己经历中一直思念的人就是亚诺。亚诺也曾对艾丽丝说过，”我一直是那个愿意为你偷苹果的男孩。“         “我们的所作所为、我们现在拥有的一切，都将随我们自己一起消逝。”         致敬亚诺，再见了艾丽丝。          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~                  dlc剧情不算长，场景不多，任务场景以地洞为主。亚诺原计划前往埃及，最后他得到了放在油灯里的伊甸碎片，但他留在了巴黎只是将伊甸碎片交给别的刺客，让他们带往埃及。这大概会串联17年的埃及刺客新作。 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 个人评分    +壮阔美丽的巴黎世界    +流畅的自由奔跑    +新颖的任务与自定义内容    +女主角挺漂亮      -生硬的战斗系统     -鸡肋的联动app     -依旧繁琐的搜集内容     -主角直路奔跑动作略丑      总 : 7.7/10  继续抱头伤感去了......

I've gotta be honest, When I first saw Stellaris, I believed it would be similar to the Civ series and Endless Legends. I was even excited about the possible Halo or Sci-Fi senarios as mods. While it might encompass the 4-X strategy model, I feel that it never executes it as perfect and as enjoyable as the Civ series  My main issue include, but are not limited to; - Early game's boring: When survying systems or locating new territories, it never feels different from the start of your previous games. This isn't like Age of Empires II, where your start and stragety will vary depending on your location and the resources near you; it's more like "Well, I better get survying and wait for a habitable planet". When your given the chance to name planets and feel connected to them, they sure give no emotion to those other systems with about 3 minerals in them.  - Fleets ain't cutting it: After getting a good economy and wanting to invest it, it seems that it's mostly going into military. That's fine though, what I have an issue with is the combat.  Do you remember when the brilliant general Hannibal heroically won at the battle of Cannae with four times the enemy's numbers. Neither did I, because he was outnumbered about 1:10! So when I have pretty well upgrated ships flying into the forces of an "inferior" empire while being outnumbered 2:3 and losing, it's not really fun. I know if you increase the firerate of a fleet, it increases damage, but I feel that suggesting "numbers win" defeats the purpose of trying to upgrade an army and seeing your power increase in practice.  - AI is kinda broken: I'll admit that I would prefer to vs. a computer than a human. It's just to do with lag and my bad internet to be honest, but I got to admit, I don't like it. You remember that combat section? Yeah, it really digs into your economy when having that many ships, but somehow the AI seems to ALWAYS contains a larger fleet than me. hmmm.  I thought we got over this kinda of lazy programming stuff after the early RTS games of the 21st century and giving the AI resourse advantages (I was also playing on normal), but it seems some things never change.  And yeah, that's may subjective opinion about Stellaris. I guess 1 in 10,000 have bad service at MCdonalds and never come back, but I would like to get comments about how I could have a better time. It might be because I played the game wrong, but this isn't bloodborne or a Souls game (shoutout to HBomberGuy :) and I think I'm capable to not having to reasearch guides.

This Death guy is Tarzan with attitude and brutal weapons..... His mechanics are improved from War's in Darksiders 1, and I like the whole inventory revamp. Level upgrades is also made easier. If you didn't buy the bundle and need to buy this game after playing #1, go ahead - you'll enjoy it.  However, his voice is far more annoying (compared to War) and I honestly don't know why they make him sound like a smart-a$$... It doesn't suit him at all - some of his remarks / comments are not needed. The camera can be slightly a nuisance at times and during busy battles it's very hard to "see yourself" with body parts flying around everywhere.  It is a cool game and I'm giving it a thumbs up. Jump, climb, swing, and kill.

Havent played it too long as it's still in development, but from the time I've had with it - very nicely done, with systems working quite differently to other similar titles. Instead of grouping all your plebs and rightclicking on a task.. you select the task first, such as a building - plonk the building down, then assign a number of your plebs as builders, or the skill the building requires - really got me at first, but now I'm quite liking the way you do things, you can just click/select and get on with other tasks.  Some nice features in there too such as scrap or decaying buildings you can raid. Radiation is quite novel too, making you think harder about your positioning. Liking the way you assign sections, such as tree cutting.. instead of selecting the forester then the tree/trees.. you just assign a beacon, plonking it in the general area and letting the game AI get on with it.  Great graphics, sound and animation!  The only downside I've found soo far is the nights, they seem too long - making it hard to see what's going on in the game-world around your encampment. (Although you can fast forward time if you wish)  All in all.. I'm happy with my purchase, and look forward to spending many more hours in this intreguing game world.

Посреди ночи Петька говорит Чапаеву: "Да и хрен с ней, с этой надписью! Может, всё-таки выпьем?". Чапай отвечает: "Мы тихо не сдадимся, Легион на это может рассчитывать"

Sadly to say this game died out quite a long time ago considering it's old age and very unique taste that few gamers like myself would enjoy playing it. The short version is that this is like a hillbilly cannibal cult-themed version of Quake with modern level-design sensibilities.  Dusk is fast.  Dusk is good.  Dusk is only as long as it needs to be.  Go play Dusk.    The longer version is that it is definitely less Lovecraft than Evil Dead, and the game has a sense of humour.   Everything about Dusk is a pastiche of influences, nods, and winks.  No individual part of Dusk will come off as being truly unique, but it's put together so well that most people won't care.  Dusk is a love letter to a design ethos and an aesthetic.  Even though there appears to be something of a retro aesthetic and design revival, Dusk was an early adopter, and many are not sticking the landing quite as well.

Все скептические настроения ложны: Age of Wonders III заслуженно носит свою цифру в названии. Все в ней говорит о преемственности и уважении к серии, и при этом игра щедра на нововведения. Мир не стоит на месте, меняются внешне расы, их магические возможности, размеры армий и тактика ведения боя. В новую "старую" механику влюбляешься через несколько минут, если нравились предыдущие части серии. К слову, на моей памяти AoW III - первая за долгое время TBS, которой 3D только в плюс. Игра прекрасно выглядит, и не возникает трудностей ориентирования на стратегической карте (камень в огород HoMM V-VI). Если кому интересно, фирменный юмор (субъективно, отличительная черта серии) в описании юнитов также никуда не делся.  Спустя 11 лет Triumph Studios снова сделали прекрасную пошаговую стратегию. И, если вспомнить, каким масштабным, глубоким и значительным для геймплея и сеттинга было дополнение "Shadow Magic" для AoW II, остается только скрестить пальцы и ждать.

review: Un juego con una historia que te mantiene interesado en saber que pasara despues, aun que en una de las escenas antes de el final me hizo pensar por un momento que el final seria malo, pero por suerte no fue asi (pequeño spoiler) y ya despues de los creditos pasa algo que pienso que todos los que jugamos el primero estabamos esperando que pasara en este (fue mi parte favorita)

过年老婆视频邀请我去岳父家吃饭。阖家团圆，平安喜乐，老丈人一家人对我盛情接待。我意外丢了一只手还好心帮我接回来。年夜饭的时候岳母做了汤，煮了肉。小舅子给我夹菜，老丈人嫌弃他夹得不够多，狠狠教训了他一顿呢，让我心里传来阵阵暖意。驾照没考，岳父听了亲自叫我开车，还教我用电锯做木工，真是好感动！一家人怕我在庄园迷路，岳父时不时“伊森~伊~~~森”的呼唤我，岳母则是拿着灯笼到处找我，小姨子一路打了好几通电话，让我别在外边逗留快点回来。老婆跟我玩捉迷藏，时不时出来吓吓我，给我一个惊喜。小舅子年纪小，爱玩，尤其喜欢和我玩，还经常搞什么生日宴会。做各种机关和陷阱让我跃跃欲试，赢了还会有奖励，我可喜欢他了。老奶奶虽然沉默寡言，但是她的房间里竟然还有玩具，可见她童心未泯，要是她不是那么衰老的话，真想和她好好说说话。总之这趟庄园之旅，意外的舒适惬意啊！

The best successor to Master of Orion 2 that I know of.  Pros:  - great visuals for systems and galaxy  - great music  - about 10 playable factions with differences in tech threes  - core gameplay is great. Exploration, expansion, exploitation and extermniation.  Cons:  - space combat is always automated  - space combat looks bad  - space battles are limited to only few ships, which, combined with retreat option, turns space war into game of cat and mouse  - random events feel lacking  - not enough diversity for heroes (as in, there are 5 main traits, and each hero is just combination of two)  - going "wide" is always a better option compared to going "tall".  - AI gets so much bonuses on hardest difficulties that it makes multiplayer crash.  - one of hero abilities is so broken that a fleet with a hero who doesn't have such ability will get completely destroyed by an equal fleet with that ability doing almost no damage.  - diplomacy is really weak.  I give it a 5 out of 5 because no one managed to do it better yet.

7/10 cuz single player the game is a blast and super fun for the first like 4 play throughs, when your trying to complete every legacy for every difficulty, but the game is pretty glitchy, and you'll find them all out as you play, the biggest one being the walls and doorways get sticky.  But then we try to review the game for when we play on nightmare or hardcore mode...I'd go with 3/10 cuz it's fun to watch your friends die in horrible ways, not just because of the impossible amount of spawning zombies, or the fact that everyone gets collision issues with each other, nor the fact that the server ping can make your vehicles collide on the road (flinging them into the air at max speed then crashing down onto the earth in a dramatic explosion leaving you and your friends dead). But this aspect gets pretty old and people do actually wanna be able to progress or beat the game...well you can't do it alone or in 2 player. So make some friends if you wanna beat the game 100% with a team of four and pray to the ping gods that you don't get each other horribly eaten. :) Pretty much same for doing daybreak mode, bring your friends and die together, not alone! Heartland mode is more story driven and is actually one of the best aspects of the game in my opinion. I'd be generous and give it a 9/10 cuz the mainline bugs are still there, but the story and extra loving details make it easier to sigh through.

game: Fallout New Vegas Honest Hearts PCR
review: [h1]Fallout New Vegas: Honest Hearts.[/h1] [i]By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea we wept, when we remembered Zion.[/i]  Fallout New Vegas: Honest Hearts is a stark change in pace in terms of the environment when compared to the base game, but still has the true "Fallout" feel at its core. Zion Valley is an un-nuked, pristinely preserved, refreshing location to immerse yourself within; and offers an intriguing backstory with lots to explore. Tribals, both friendly and hostile, inhabit this fertile land; and it's up to The Courier to resolve the conflicts between these tribes. The subtle undertones of this narrative adds loads to the experience too, and are what makes this DLC still, distinctly, a Fallout tale.  Honest Hearts begins when you receive a radio message from the Happy Trails Caravan Company, informing you that they need people for a trading expedition into Utah. Upon reaching the man organizing the caravan, he lets you know that you aren't allowed to carry more than 75lbs of personal gear on the journey (100lbs if you pass a skill check), and then you're off. A slideshow details the history of where you're headed - New Canaan - which also happens to be the birthplace of the "Burned Man", of Caesars Legion legend. Along the way the caravan makes a pit-stop in Zion Valley, where sh*t hits the fan; leaving you alone in hostile territory, but also, among some splendid scenery.  The Zion Valley is a rarity in the world of Fallout, in that it appears to be nearly completely unscathed by the Great War 200 years previous. The land is filled with flora and wildlife, and has an uncontaminated river flowing through it all, which often reflects crystal blue skies. And, even when it is overcast, the clouds are healthy enough to provide rain to Zion, undoubtedly fueling its brimming ecosystem. Caves and landmarks dot the canyon, authentically conveying the atmosphere of a real national park. Without a doubt, the setting of Honest Hearts is a real treat.  Though admittedly a bit linear in structure, the main quest-line of HH is very enjoyable. The majority of these missions have several options as to how you complete them, and serve to get you accustomed to Zion and the predicaments of the people who live there. There are also a few side quests, which offer even more choices, and are generally more dialogue-heavy than the main quests. All of these adventures relate back to Zion itself however, as the main point of these quests seems to be to get you out and exploring the lovely landscape, and learning about the valley.  The characters in Honest Hearts are, for the most part, duller than that of the previous DLC (Dead Money), but each one serves a greater purpose. There is a message about tribalism, religion, family, and what is and isn't righteous woven underneath the plot, which is communicated perfectly by the differing characters, of whom all are needed to craft this message. The relationships the player creates with these personas will be dependent on what they believe is and isn't right - which will cause you to make choices, and take sides. What you decide will have profound effects on the futures of the characters and Zion, which is a staple of the Fallout series; choice and consequence. There is one more character though, one who predates all others, and is possibly more important than all of them...  The history of The Zion Valley is chiefly chronicled by terminal notes left behind by one man, who survived the nuclear holocaust and took shelter in the caves of the park. I won't spoil his story, but the tale of this "Survivalist" is, in my opinion, the best piece of environmental storytelling told by any game, ever. The trials and tribulations he faced in Zion are heartbreaking, riveting, bad-a*s, and deeply engrossing. He is so well written that he actually inspires reverence from the player, and is in fact worshipped by the tribals of Zion, yet in an ignorant and unknowing way. This side-narrative connects to the main plot several times throughout your stay in Zion, and is my favorite part about HH by far.  Altogether, Honest Hearts comprises 8 hours of top-quality content, and is one of my favorite DLCs of all time. The narrative it tells is exceedingly original, and packed with fragments of true genius throughout. All of the RPG elements were nailed without fault as well; with a great variety of choices to make, characters to invest in, and places to go. I couldn't recommend Honest Hearts any more highly, to all Fallout: New Vegas players. Jugué DC Universe antes y pensé que era el juego de heroes definitivo, pero la concepción de free for play de Sony es bastante desconcertante, no has acabado el tutorial y ya están limitandote la falta de los DLC porque no puedes seguir las aventuras que el juego ofrece, la experiencia se interrumpe porque los desarrolladores presionan prematuramente por algún pago, para mí DC Universe Online es una demo enorme, juegas pero es necesario pagar para seguir.   Creo que el formato free to play consiste en que los usuarios puedan jugar sin limitaciones y las incorporaciones por pago no afectan la calidad de la experiencia del juego, la sorpresa al jugar Champios Online fue agradable, es un verdadero free to play sin limitantes de los infames DLC, realmente estoy disfrutando un juego que no tiene nada que envidiarle a DC Universe, al principio parece que no es igual a DC Universe porque tu personaje no vuela o no tiene super velocidad pero eso lo verás en el level 6 al que llegas realmente rápido, los poderes que te ofrecen parecen limitados, pero es igual en DC Universe pero no deja de dar opciones a explorar, lo mejor de todo es la customización del personaje, no tendras uno igual a otro sin duda, además no se nota la codicia, Champion Online me ha encaganchado y  realmente le invertiré en el futuro, un free to play debe convencer al usuario que vale la pena invertir en el juego, no obligarlo a comprar dando probaditas estilo "traficante de drogas", voy con el concepto de que un free to play debe ser como Dota 2, Team Fortress, Star Conflict, Haken, donde las mejoras por pago no afectan directamente la experiencia del juego como tal, salvo mejoras cosmeticas o en su defecto mejoras en la ganancia de puntos, por eso no es bueno llamar DC Universe free to play, es pay to win, punto. Lástima que en esa modalidad de falsos free to play caen muchos: Dungeons & Dragons Online, Lord of the Ring Online y otros de la misma empresa.

I do not even know where to begin.   There are some amazing ideas in this game, and it seems a lot of polish even during early access.  The diplomacy is unique and very complex, with influence and interactions that feel very very real.  The planetary resource systems are fascinating to me, as is the resulting trade networks that grow organically.  The ship builder is actually better than the first Star Ruler, which had an amazing ship builder.  FTL was weak in Star Ruler 1, here there are 5 different methods each unique and tactical.  Combat seems solid, manageable, and interesting.  The flagship system means that you are ordering around fleets, not ships, but you still have a nice amount of control and the ship numbers are amazing.   Everything is . . . perfect.  I'm a highly critical gamer with jaded tastes.  I've been disappointed by one 4x game after another.  MoO3, Endless Space, Sword of the Stars 2, all sad memories.  Even Galciv and Distant Worlds weren't quite good enough for me.  I have never been so completely blown away just playing a tutorial, realizing the depth of the systems I'm seeing laid out in front of me.  Assuming there is nothing horribly wrong with this game that is hidden from me currently . . . well damn, I'll say it, this might be the game that surpasses Master of Orion 2.  It's an overused cliche, but it fits with this game.  Things could go wrong, the AI may turn out to be useless, or some other chronic mistake, but I don't think so.  Star Ruler 1 was visionary and flawed, fascinating but clunky.  It seems they learned a lot from that game.  Seeing this come from a small studio . . . I hope it gains the accolades it deserves.  I also suspect modding will be amazing, since Star Ruler 1 had a wonderful modding scope, and I suspect they did the same here.  Buy this game.  No seriously, if you like 4x gaming at all, buy Star Ruler 2.  This isn't a game you buy just to support the ideas of the devs, though those ideas are amazing.  This is the game I wish I had paid more for, because I think I cheated the devs and got way more than I paid for.  :::Post-release:::  The game remains very strong, with several major improvements over the beta.  The ship design remains the high point of the game, and sadly the AI remains a little weak.  The AI is competent, certainly.  It does know how to play the game properly, but it lacks aggression.  On the other hand, it is smart enough to know when it has lost.    I won a game recently without actually taking a single enemy planet.  I out-expanded them slightly, and while they fought wars against each other, I offered surrender to whichever side was near to losing.  Most of them accepted subjugation, since I was a friendly power that was roughly 10 times their strength.  After I did this three times, I turned on the one remaining AI.  I declared war, sent my massive ships.  Three of my ships arrived in their systems and I received an offer of surrender before they could reach the planet.  I think they just saw the ships blotting out the sun and said "Nope, this is not winnable."  That is smart design and saved me a long slog to a certain victory.  Recent improvements to the tech tree have made it far more understandable and elegant.  Technology in general seems far more unique and useful as compared to the beta tech tree, which was somewhat repetitive.  Performance remains very good, I've yet to see a bug or crash in any of my games.  The races and various FTL methods have vastly improved from the beta, and the AI knows how to play every combination without error.  The modding community is rapidly expanding, as predicted, and has already furnished several very solid mods.  The devs have already incorporated some of the best additions as core gameplay, which does not surprise me.  I still recommend this game highly, it remains a very original and solid 4x game.  I have high hopes for the future, and I do feel they have delivered a solid game as it currently stands.  Of course, I always yearn for more.

game: Train Sim World®: Northeast Corridor New York
review: So the first error was having high hopes for a plesant route. Never have high hopes! Zero train diversity. Could've at least thrown in NJ transit or a Metroliner in there as an Ai at bare minimum. 125mph? Nope! 94 if you just don't give an F about anything after a while.  High qualtiy train models and stations but effing sheat just lacks immersion like others point out. Nothing new for TSW after all. To make this content demo of a simulator go somewhere before retirement creeps up, community dev tools is the solution and  in desperate need.  There's abandonment lurking in the air already and we are only 3 dlc in.

[i]Disclaimer:  I started playing this game with Patch 1.6 (!) It took me about 10-20 hours to actually get suck into the game mechanics and story/characters. There are still bugs in the game, although nowhere near as much as there have been. The occasional car suddenly tripping over something and making an air flip because of it...which is not progress stopping but breaks the immersion a bit.[/i]  [h1]..::What I didn't like about the game::..[/h1] - gazillion of written Texts as "shards" which I stopped reading after the second one, maybe I missed good bits and parts of the whole universe, but to me it was just to annoying always stopping what you just where doing to read plain text - [b]combat system[/b], started the game on hard difficulty, most enemies felt like bullet sponges, going stealthy with takedowns was much easier in the beginning. This gets better once you try to develop your build - the big city doesn't feel as alive as it should be - "battle hubs" scattered around the city feel weird, gang members standing around and as soon as you get too close they get hostile, you have no clue why (its mostly for getting XP and money in the game, besides normal gigs) - police system is a joke, luckily I rarely had to deal with it  [h1]::..What I liked about this game..::[/h1] - [b]the fucking music[/b]! (most of them available on streaming platforms) there is so many amazing music titles in this game and also ambient which will grab you by the balls and drives home the feeling of the whole game... - ...which is by its heart a very distinct dystopian view. Night City is not for the weak. People die left and right. Night City might seem like a decent location at first, but soon it will rear its ugly head and you will realise its not - [b]missions[/b], be it side or main missions, most of them felt very engaging and added to the world and story - [b]characters[/b]: this game is driven by its amazing characters. Without spoiling too much I just want to say that it reminded me of the good days back with Mass Effect 1-2, where you got strongly attached to your crew members, be it romantically or not (e.g. Jackie, Johnny Silverhand, Panam Palmer, Judi Alvarez) - [b]endings[/b] are so worthwhile and satisfying, rarely have I felt so strongly about how a game finishes (although I must admit I probably got the "best" ending on my first playthrough) - [b]dialogues[/b]: depending on your starting background you have different dialogue options throughout the game which feels nice and very fitting - vehicles have very different handling and there is a ton of different options out there - [b]combat system[/b]: once you get to unlock later perks and use modifications which further increase your strategy, combat can feel quite powerful. Quickhacks are amazingly strong later on, whereas in the beginning they are mostly utility (deactivating a camera just by scanning it compared to killing a whole group of people without firing a single bullet or using any melee weapon at all) - sheer scale of Night city is amazing, when you focus on the main-plot you will see 30% of the city at most, most of it needs to be explored through side jobs/gigs - side quest with sprinkles of nice ideas (talking gun, talking soda vending machine, sentient cars)

Hollow Knight es un juego de 1 en 1 millon, y es uno de los más claros exponentes de que los indies no solo son un gran potencial, sino que pueden luchar contra los juegos AAA. Una de las más grandes genialidades del juego, es que incluso la historia tienes que buscarla y descubrirla, ademas de tener que explorar un mundo lleno de personajes carismáticos, también es un mundo lleno de retos de los cuales los más habilidosos tendrán la dicha de completarlos. En conclusión, es un juego 10/10 y uno de mis juegos favoritos.

Excelente juego, muy divertido y repleto de acción que utiliza un estilo simple pero muy llamativo y característico. La historia puede llegar a ser confusa (sobre todo si no jugaste al primer juego) pero es entretenida y posee un mensaje muy único y que va acorde al género de este juego y los juegos violentos en general. Por eso recomiendo mucho comprarlo con el primer título y empezar con ese, ya que el mensaje "oculto" y la historia se entienden mucho mejor al seguirlo cronológicamente, pero por si solo se mantiene bien. Llega a ser desafiante y posee un modo difícil, además de un editor de niveles, donde podés crear tu propio nivel y compartirlo con los demás jugadores en la workshop de steam del juego, así como poder descargar niveles de otras personas.  Recomendado.

I've played a lot of games in my time, and I'll say this straight away before I say anything else, I'm not a massive fan of RPG games. Something about a lot of them just don't interest me in the slightest, albeit there are some exceptions.  However, The Witcher 3 is an absolute masterpiece, I had tried to play the game a long time ago and really did not enjoy the first part of the game while you're in the White Orchard, after that part though, the game kicks off. I have never been as engaged or enjoyed a game as much as this one, in fact, I'll say it's one of the best games I've ever played, almost everything about it feels so perfectly crafted, so much passion put into it. If you're a fan of immersive story telling, definitely try this if you haven't already.

Note: A key was provided by the developer for the purposes of the reviewing but it does not change my opinions of the game.  [h1]The Mooseman[/h1]  [h1]Gameplay [/h1]  I’ve always been fascinated by various myths associated with different cultures. Reading about them was the most fun I had in my cultural classes so when I saw The Mooseman, I was immediately interested in the way it was presented. The game puts you in the shoes of the Mooseman, a person who can see and interact with the spirit world.   While the game has a story and it is presented to you in some gibberish language while the English translation is written on the screen, it is the mythic lore and the snippets of this world the game presents to you that are the most interesting. The Mooseman does not tell you what you have to do or what is going on exactly and leaves it to be found by you.   The gameplay in The Mooseman is pretty simple, you walk left and right using the arrow keys and a press of the space button which taps you into the spirit world. While it seems pretty simple, the game requires you to have an acute sense of your surroundings, both normal and the spirit realm.   The puzzles are mostly around that which requires you to switch back and forth into the spirit and normal realms. These puzzles were refreshing and require you to actually pay attention to what’s going on. New enemies are introduced without much hustle and bustle and while they might kill you a couple of times, it is only about time how to get past them.   Right from the beginning, The Mooseman grips you in its carefully thought out world and the mythical beasts. As you pass by certain landmarks, you get little snippets of lore which gives you information on what or where you just passed by. These pieces of story are interesting to say the least and for once I was actually reading what was it that I just experienced.   There are certain objects you can walk and interact in the normal world while in the spirit realm, you might just fall through them and vice versa. This makes sense and in turn also gives some really good puzzles for you to solve. You will also die a lot in The Mooseman but this is not a game where it gets frustrating because of the said deaths. The Mooseman gives you more than enough chances to try again and again to solve these puzzles.   You respawn right before where you died and while deaths might feel cheap, they never go into the territory of frustrating. There is never that feeling of losing progression and that makes it all the more exciting. There are also collectibles in the form of lost artifacts which might increase replayablity for some but most of them are pretty easy to find and some obscure ones feel  impossible to reach and I didn’t feel like replaying just for some of those.  The major problem of the The Mooseman is also the same thing that I loved about it. Some puzzles are difficult to solve since sometimes you might miss a couple of clues here and there. The main story itself is kind of stretched in parts but those are minor nitpicks in what is otherwise a great experience. This is one of a kind game which does not depend on your reflexes but rather on the surroundings you are in and it does a great job of it.  [h1]Visuals[/h1]  Some people might compare this to something like LIMBO in terms of its visuals and they would not be all wrong but I found the visuals in this game far more interesting and engaging. The Mooseman depends on its visuals and everything, especially in the spirit realm, looks near perfect.   Little visual hints to solve the puzzles are also done very well. The Mooseman’s visual style made me creeped out and awestruck at the same time and this world is something I will remember for quite some time.  [h1]Sound[/h1]  The sound design in The Mooseman is done very well and there is a certain creepy vibe to it that just feels right. There is some voice acting but it is one of the game's mythic language so that is not much helpful. It does add another layer of mystery and authenticity of the world.   [h1]Overall[/h1]  I absolutely loved The Mooseman. But I do feel that it might not be for everyone since the amount of gameplay is pretty limited and the game requires more than some other reflex based games do. It is also priced pretty perfectly and you might want to give it a try if you are looking for something different. EDIT: Customers: "Looks like GTAV is finally getting it's reviews back up since the last big issue."  Rockstar: "Hold my beer." *insert launcher that literally no one wanted*  Older Review:::: I'm a little split down the middle weather I recommend this game of not (Yes even if I have over 600 hours of gameplay)  GTA Storymode: Storymode is amazing, I love all the characters, the character shifting keeps it fast paced, and it's a big map full of dumb shit to do. Though it was bullshit that they got rid of offline modding, at least OpenIV is back. Story mode is top notch.  GTA Online: Online is where I spent the majority of my 600+ hours, there's plenty to do and, with friends, you can spend a long time of having fun on this. The problem though is that fact that everything simply costs too much money and anytime players find a good way to make money in game that doesn't make you want to pull your hair out, Rockstar nerfs it (*cough* the kuruma method in PS heist *cough*). The lack of being able to do the heist different (non hack/mod/exploits) ways makes getting money a chore and usually more annoying than what it's worth. Though, of course, it's like this to get players to spend REAL money on shark cards, a very shitty and greedy move. Not only that, but I find innocent non hackers/modders getting banned and punished more often than the actual hackers/modders. Hackers/Modders run rampant, more so lately than usualy, which (if you run into the douchey ones), can make the game crappy to play.  The story mode itself is a great and fun experiance but with online in the state that it is, I just can't bring myself to recommend the game to someone unless you get it for cheap or something.

Essa é uma reimaginação incrível de Tyrian, de 1995. É meio sucessor espiritual, meio uma versão remix, que atualiza os gráficos e músicas originais em uma experiência mais ampla e experimental, mas que mantém a atmosfera, o estilo e o sentimento do jogo de 1995.   Por ser inteiramente feito por um único desenvolvedor, incluindo arte e música, é um pouco amador em alguns aspectos e certamente precisa de alguns ajustes e polimento, mas é incrível o que o desenvolvedor alcançou. Há uma galáxia para explorar de forma aberta e os dados coletados nas fases revelam segredos e missões, que dão algum senso de direção, sem precisar segurar na mão do jogador.   Há uma boa dose de complexidade, especialmente no sistema de distribuição de energia, o ponto mais polêmico do jogo. Eu mesmo achei muito complexo e confuso no começo, e levei bastante tempo para entender bem seu funcionamento e começar a tirar proveito dele. Ao chegar neste ponto, ele se torna muito interessante, permitindo um grau minuciosos de personalização e estratégia (houve uma fase em que eu reduzi a velocidade de movimentação vertical para aumentar meu poder de fogo e deu super certo!). O problema é que falta um tutorial para explicar melhor seu funcionamento.   Além disso, como o jogo é super aberto, é fácil sair da "rota principal" (se é que isso existe) e acabar indo para planetas muito difíceis. Em meu jogo, acabei fazendo uma certa dose de grind, fiquei super poderoso e agora ele está em geral muito mais fácil do que no começo. E definitivamente isso não é um problema, é a experiência que eu estou tendo e que provavelmente vai ser muito diferente de outros jogadores.   É um jogo muito mais sobre exploração, descobertas e experimentação do que um shoot 'em up convencional, o que é ótimo!

To the new player looking for a new game to play, don't be [b]misguided[/b] by the late [b]reviews[/b]. The developers have been doing a great job since the start of the game, providing loads of content with constant updates. There have been many big conceptual changes, like the 'early access' tag still suggests, however this plays much like a finished game to me, and I don't think they will make any more huge changes to the core mechanics.  [h1]Level progression[/h1] You are provided higher CPU (amount and quality of blocks you can use on each robot you build) as you level up, however you may [b]get epic or legendary parts from the start[/b], and use them right away. Before this, you were forced to make temporary bots that would last until your next tier level up, and all your blocks would become obsolete. Tier progression became slower and slower, and it was no fun knowing that your bot would become useless later (lower tiers provided much, much less cash per game). Now I have 3 main bots, one of them of around 450 cpu (about 1/3rd of the game's max cpu) and I'm getting quite good rewards by winning matches.  [h1]The action[/h1] It's great. Especially when you have friends to play and coordinate with. It's a skill-based game (I make it count), but there are some rock-paper-scissor and situational mechanics in too: Railgun beats plane, missiles beat slow, artillery beats light, AA beats hover and air, ion beats close, etc. Teamplay is paramount especially in Battle Arena mode. You will sometimes be surrounded by enemy bots, shooting you with full arsenal, as you try to run away with your remaining leg and laser gun, until your just-respawning allies come from behind the hill to blast their parts away and push the front towards their base once more. It's funny how things get partially destroyed and still remain functional sometimes... or not so much.  [b]There really isn't any pay2win involved[/b] (I haven't paid a dime and have everything I need). The only thing I dislike about the business model is that the only way you can use all paint colors is by renting premium, so if you want to add something to your bot after your premium has expired you can't paint it right unless you pay or get a promo code again. Colors already in your bot get to stay, however.  [h1]Balance[/h1] The [i]Ion Distorter[/i] (a shotgun-like weapon) is a bit OP, but I always find it easy to destroy any before my opponent gets close enough to fire it. [i]Tesseracts[/i] are an imposing type of robot which some players seem to be building, and it is quite hard to kill, however it can be countered with any AA gun if your team knows to prioritize well. So basically, there are a few components and combinations which, if analyzed alone, are overpowered. However there is [b]always[/b] a way to counter them, with either [b]skill[/b] or [b]teamwork[/b]. Both things I love to find in a game.   [h1]The new loot system[/h1] After each game, players are awarded a loot box of varying qualities depending on how well they did in a game. Half of the contents within these boxes are premium-locked. The loot system makes rewards much more appealing (people always choose the mystery box :P) however they are certainly more random. In the long run, you [i]will[/i] get many epics and maybe even one or two legendaries. One thing to note is that the devs will probably get more premium subscriptions from players who get their epic/legendary in the locked part of their reward loot, but hey they need to make money too. Overall, I personally seem to [b]accumulate riches much, much faster[/b] than in previous updates, and it all comes down to how well you do in games and the possibility to have premium.  [h1]Conclusion[/h1] To finish up, I'd like to say that Robocraft, in its current state, still remains a very creative, skill-rewarding, and overall fun game to spend my casual gaming time on. You can trust the devs to keep working on it, adding content and improving features in the months, and maybe years to come. Stop reading those red reviews and try it for a couple of days yourself. You'll enjoy it way past that timeframe!

I spent a half hour writing a bigger review for this game, clicked on the wrong spot, and lost all my work. So I'll keep it brief:  [u]For the king is:[/u] - Great fun with a small group of friends(party cap of 3) - Best experienced using something like Discord or Skype for communication - Playable without friends - Very replayable, as the maps and events are procedurally-generated for each campaign - Full of unlockables in the lore shop(which I might add, is done [b]exclusively with in game currency[/b] earned through playing the game) - Great if you like a bit of a challenge.   My friends and I were never confused on what to do, or where to go. The difficulty felt just right for us, and the simple player interactions were entertaining and straightforward. Despite the game telling us not to expect to win on our first try, [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/560175317075886110/704132990388928542/unknown.png]we pulled through[/url](albeit with two of us dead and out of lives) in the end! And that was only the first of [b]six campaigns[/b] that are [b]free with the game![/b]  I fully recommend this game to RPG lovers and first-timers alike, and must say it is well worth the $22.79 price tag. If you can't spare that, the game goes on sale fairly regularly for about $10. Additionally, at the time of writing this review it's free on the Epic games launcher. So treat yourself to what is bound to become a new favorite, and grab yourself this game!

Real talk? This game is fantastic. The story isn't anything overly complex (at least for me since I'm a story snob who plays tons of JRPGs and massive VNs), but the world that it builds is interesting and there are a select few scenes that continue to blow my mind from how phenomenal they were even a month after beating the game. That aside, the characters are fun and serve the story well, but the biggest things you'll want to play this game for are the art style, the music, and bar none the gameplay of Virgo vs. The Zodiac is some of the best I've experienced in recent years. The pixel art and animations are cute and smooth as all hell, the music is *absurdly* good (I bought and listen to the OST frequently, something I rarely do for even the steam releases I really like), and the combat mechanics are a breath of fresh air from all the cookie cutter RPG titles you can find lying around nowadays. It focuses on an 'elemental triangle' that's based on the story's theme/lore, a secondary HP bar of sorts called 'purity' which protects your main health and lets you counterattack when hit, and your equipment decides every single one of your skills. So not only are the base mechanics unique and fun to mess with,  My only genuine complaints are that there was one ice puzzle that I got stuck on for half an hour, but I'm just horrible at ice puzzles to begin with, and at least when it first released, it was a bit unclear what you needed to do to get different endings and what affected them. Past that, the story *could* be better, but it certainly doesn't do anything wrong, and I'm going to be following this dev's future projects without a doubt.  Easy 8.5/10. 9/10 if you're good at ice puzzles, which I am not.

The Long Dark. My very first play through.  The setting is you are stranded in the Canadian wilderness during winter. First time I played that game I had found a rifle and three rounds, but had run out of food in the trapper’s cabin I had been crashing in. So I set out on a hike to try and find anything I can to eat.  I end up in a partially collapsed train tunnel, just saving up some energy while I figure out where to go next. Suddenly, I notice a Buck passing by. I raise my rifle but don’t have a clear shot, so I start following his tracks.  I follow for a few minutes and see him go over a hill top. I start sprinting up the hill with all my backpack gear clanking together. But when I reach the top, I realize too late what was happening...  The Buck had stopped to graze not far from me - and had caught the attention of a wolf coming from the other direction. The wolf had been stalking its prey and was about ready to strike when I showed up. But my noisy Boy Scout charge had alerted the Buck it was being followed and he took off.  The wolf doesn’t even try to pursue the Buck. Instead, he turns to me with this low snarling growl and is enraged that I made him miss his kill.  Almost immediately, the wolf starts charging towards me. I line up my shot and pull the trigger. Nothing. I hadn’t loaded any of my three rounds into the gun. No time. I end up timing a melee strike by swinging my gun like a baseball bat. Contact made! The wolf yelps, but quickly turns back around, knocks me to the ground, and messes me up pretty good before I land a last melee and the wolf runs off, leaving a blood trail behind him.  I’m also bleeding out, my clothes are shredded. I walk a few paces, fall down and pass out. I wake up hours later. I’m alive! But dusk is setting in and the temperature has dropped bitterly. I start limping back towards the train tunnel - leaving a blood trail of my own. With some luck, I make it back right at nightfall. The temperature is now -20F. I MUST build a fire.  I have enough kindling for three attempts at starting a fire. All fail. That’s when I realize it’s game over - but before the credits roll, I will have to just sit here and wait for death to take me. I had survived the wolf attack and bloody walk back, only to freeze to death now...  Just as I start to succumb to the cold, I notice a few wolves approaching, sniffing at my blood trail. They look up and see me lying there at a distance. The last thing I hear is them howling into the night sky.  “You’ve faded into the long dark.”  Update 2019: Love the new story mode!  Update 2020: Voting for Labor of Love Steam Award

This is by far my favorite game i’ve played. Before Rocket League i was very much into the FPS genre and never really considered RL. I’m also a very avid soccer (football) player but games like fifa were just unappealing. Then my school started an Esports league and the games were smite, rl, and league. The only one i had any kind of interest in was rl, so i started playing casually with friends with school and very quickly got addicted. I still cannot pinpoint what exactly about rl that makes it such a great game but it is.  Not to say that it doesn’t have problems, development and fixes are painfully slow. Features that are so blatantly obvious that they should be put in aren’t. Even features that are already in the game like tournaments are broken. I wish they cared a little more about their game but whatever. i’ll still be playing it regardless. So if you’re considering buying rl, go for it. it’s pretty rad.

game: Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut
review: Sene 2027. Teknoloji o biçim. Böyle kolunu bacağını iç organlarını kaybeden, yerine yüksek teknoloji ürünü sibernetik protezler satın alıyor. Satın alıyor diyorum çünkü öyle ssk, sgk, yeşil kart filan yok bu evrende. Kapitalizmin arşa çıktığı bir düzen var. Parayı basan düdüğü çalar misali, bir yerden tanıdık geldi dimi. Evet çünkü günümüzde de böyle. Aradan 7 sene geçmiş fakat gelişen yalnızca teknoloji olmuş, insanlık yerinde saymış.   Ana karakterimizden bahsedelim. Adam jensen. Kim bu adam ? Sıradan bir adam. Daha önce SWAT timinde görev almış, özel operasyonlar yürütmüş eski bir taktisyen polistir kendisi. Oldukça sıradan değil mi :) Hikayenin devamını tahmin edebilirsiniz, aradığını bulamamış, işler sarpa sarmış bla bla bla... Daha sonra Sarif Endüstrisinde güvenlik şefi olarak işe başlıyor. Bu şirket aug teknolojisi ürünlerinin önde gelen kuruluşlarından. Sonra şirket saldırıya uğruyor, güvenlik şefimiz hemen müdahale ediyor fakat bu saldırıyı geri püskürtmeye çalışırken vücudu harap oluyor. Sarif endüstrisi bizim elemanı 1. sınıf askeri kalitede oldukça nadir ve türünün tek örneği aug prototipiyle donatıyor mecburen. Sonracıma Adam Jensen oluyor bir terminatör. Geleni geçeni tokattlıyor, şöyle uçuyor, böyle kaçıyor derken bir anda kendimizi çetrefilli olaylar zincirinde buluyoruz. İndirimde 5 tl ye kadar düşebiliyor. 1 lt sütten ucuz. Rahatlıkla alabilirsiniz. Türkçe Yaması mevcuttur. Don’t come into Dig or Die with any preconceived expectations. Like Minecraft, it’s a survival, crafting, sandbox builder; and like Terraria, it takes place on a 2D plane. Even Starbound has a sci-fi theme and setting. Looking at Dig or Die with expectations as to what it should be, for good or for bad, is a poor way to experience the game. While not perfect, the title is fun in its own right; even if elements of the game sometimes feel derivative or uninteresting.  Dig or Die, a newly released title from Gaddy Games, takes the elements of survival block builder games and condenses them to a much tighter narrative experience. Trapped on an alien world after sales trip gone wrong, your impatient AI companion tasks you with building a new space ship to escape. Luckily as the representative of CRAFT & Co you’ve access to automated fabrication technology you can use to build bases, turrets and more. You’ll need it too.  The hostile planet you’ve crash landed on is, from the very first day, determined to kill you. All life on the death world is hostile and, if you’ve killed a member of their species, will come in droves to kill you at night. This introduces what is perhaps the most interesting mechanic in Dig or Die. Every time the sun sets, monsters spawn at an incredibly fast rate and begin to converge on your location. Until dawn rises you’re alone against swarms of vicious creatures. Building turrets and hunkering down in a bunker like a doomsday prepper is often the best you can do. Killing animals causes their kin to start seeking you out, a con that must be weighed against obtaining materials needed to progress through the game.  Indeed, Dig or Die borrows from Metroidvanias in many ways. Requiring you to craft better items to progress or forcing you to return to areas once inaccessible. Building new, more powerful weapons typically demands new mining ores. Or a stronger tool for digging minerals might require new creature drops. Feeding off each other, progression is tied to a central crafting table that must be periodically upgraded so as to make new gear that can then be used to delve deeper and deeper into the subterranean depths of the planet, uncovering even more new enemies, crafting materials and biomes. This tight progression loop and narrative experience sets Dig or Die apart from its more sandbox, “do whatever you want” competitors. Indeed, the relatively horizontal small map size, and the need to return to your downed spaceship computer for advice, constricts movement in an otherwise procedurally generated landscape. Personally, I find this sense of progression to be a positive in a world of often otherwise aimless counterparts.  The big draw for this title from Gaddy Games is this progression as well as small tweaks to the block builder formula. The gunplay feels smooth and intuitive and immediately feels different from most titles that limit you, at first, to melee weapons. The large roster of shotguns, Gatling guns and more all are fun to use. While at times a bother, the nighttime assaults on your base lend an ever-present sense of danger. “Do I continue digging, and potentially get caught at night unprotected? Or do I risk it to hopefully find some better crafting material?” The fast and frenetic swarm battles are a highlight that truly test your base building and combat skills. Still, for what Dig or Die giveth it also taketh away.  While some might argue Minecraft, subject to nearly ten years of patches, updates and new content, is bloated, it offers a much more interesting experience than Dig or Die. The world, despite supposedly holding millions of creatures poised to kill you, is somewhat sterile. Other than the occasional enemy or simple plant there’s not much to see. Biomes are not nearly as interesting or plentiful as they could be. The sheer number of building tools, biomes, creatures and items found in other games are simply not present here. While not ugly, the art style and animations of the world, its creatures and the player, is very simple and plain. I didn’t find myself wanting to come back this game nearly as often as I had other, more famous, titles. Probably thanks, in part, to the much more limited building options that limits creativity. Despite these flaws, Dig or Die is a very capable title and a testament to what developer passion can churn out.  For players interested in a more streamlined experience Dig or Die delivers. It’s a tight, combat heavy, building and crafting game. While plain and somewhat empty it nevertheless provides a unique, if not altogether engaging, experience. Without the huge amounts of content provided by its competition Dig or Die makes up for its flaws with smooth combat, a streamlined story and a responsive crafting feedback loop. With room for future improvements and new content Gaddy Games could make something to rival long established champions of the genre.  8/10

Je remercie ........................ Creative Assembly et TOTAL WAR: Rome 2 qui m'ont donné l'occasion d'investir mes ronds dans Crusader Kings 2. Comme beaucoup, j'avais mis trois thunes de côté, mais après l'avoir testé chez un pote et lu les nombreuses critiques, j'ai préféré claquer mes sous dans CK2. J'étais franchement attiré par l'aspect stratégique, autrement plus poussé que dans TW:R2, mais - comme beaucoup, je pense - craignais de trop ressentir l'absence de rencontres tactiques. De fait, c'était idiot, et, de mon point de vue le jeu se suffit amplement à lui-même (en même temps, c'est normal, mais bon). L'interface et la carte sont vraiment travaillées, les principes de gestion bien dosés tout en étant assez touffus pour ne pas s'emmerder, et les aspects diplomatie ainsi que certains évènements ne manquent pas d'humour ce qui ne gâte rien.... J'enquille les heures de jeu sans regarder ma montre, ça fait un bail que ça ne m'était pas arrivé! Seul petit bémol, comme souvent, la floppée de DLC pas forcèment indispensables pour certains, mais qui rehaussent indubitablement les possibilités tout en alourdissant la facture finale. A mon avis, il faut vraiment se concentrer sur la gestion de la Dynastie, et ne pas trop chercher à conserver coûte que coûte son teritoire. De fait, il arrive que l'on se retrouve à la tête d'un empire assez rapidement avec un personnage talentueux, pour voir l'oeuvre du premier réduite à néant par une fratrie de frustrés et un héritier débile... Au début, ça me stressait, mais finalement, il vaut mieux jouer le jeu et s'arranger pour que les générations suivantes assurent la reconquête... Après tout c'était l'une des grosses faiblesses de la féodalité.  Pour finir, je précise également qu'il tourne comme un manège sur linux, voire mieux que sur Windaube (mais non, je ne suis pas chauvin!) (config: kubuntu 13.10 et chakra-linux). Content de voir que Paradox se met à la page de ce côté-là, j'espère que le portage des HoI et Victorias I et II suivront.  A la proxima...

Серия Counter-Strike не нуждается в представлении. Знаменитый командный шутер, в котором игроки изучили каждый пиксель, продолжает жить и здравствовать. Пусть выходят пачками Call of Duty, Battlefield наращивает масштаб карт, а Left 4 Dead предлагает увлекательные кооперативные режимы — бесконечное противостояние террористов и спецназа в Counter-Strike по-прежнему собирает на серверах тысячи игроков по всему миру.  Чтобы не распугать старых фанатов, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, вышедшая буквально несколько дней назад, должна была сохранить все принципиальные особенности великой серии. У нее это определенно получилось: если вы долгие часы просиживали в Source и 1.6, то и в новой Counter-Strike будете чувствовать себя, как дома. Кроме владельцев PC, поиграть в новую Counter-Strike теперь могут и владельцы консолей Xbox 360 и PS 3. Правда, на одном поле они никогда не встретятся.  Правила игры просты. Есть две команды: одна атакует, другая защищается. Нет никаких классов. Цели, как и раньше, — заложить бомбу и взорвать объект, или спасти заложников, или уничтожить команду врага. После каждого раунда точно так же можно купить новое оружие и броню. Карты все те же самые: Dust, Italy, Nuke, Train, Dust 2, Aztec, Office и Inferno.  Давно знакомый геймплей подается в новой, существенно похорошевшей графике с реалистичным освещением и проработанными моделями оружия и бойцов. Казалось бы, это всего-навсего та же самая игра, только в красивой обертке. Но стоит изучить Global Offensive повнимательней, и становится понятно, что над ней провели колоссальную работу.

this game is so good it has taken almost two thousand hours off my life!!!, this game is simply outstanding with how replayable it is because there are 8 origins that all play differently (especially tinkerer and disquieted) and the fact campaign has 28 awsome missions where you get to see all your favorite characters from the MC (my favorites being the homies sanford and deimos). the voice acting is also something i have to shine praise on because every character has a different voice and different lines, Sanford's voice is the best for me beause he is so passionate!!. when he shouts "WEAK!" or "KABOOM!!" you really feel his enthusiasm for blowing shit up and taking peoples heads off. and now i will praise the graphics, they are really epic and the 3D really adds a uniqueness to the game series vs the animations that i really enjoy not to mention that looming nostalgia for those 3D games i used to play on sites like miniclip.com, armorgames.com and the birthplace of madness Newgrounds itself. now for things i dont like, the lack of bossfights is really sad considering the vast options to choose from the animations and potential to introduce new scary/epic boss fights their are currently only 5 or 6 bossfights if i remember correctly. MINOR SPOILER WARNING: ||Mag bandit, Sherrif, Christoff, H.I.V.E monster, tower guards and hank are the only boss fights in the game||.  also the most annoying thing by far that i dislike the most is how heavy weapons are handled, the long and painfull animation before the swing finishes gives enemies enough time to kill you (or if your massive take a corpus) and enemies can walk away from the attack mid-animation. however don't let this distract you from the fact this game is a 8.5/10!!!!

Хм, странная игра и всё что угодно, но это не стратегия. Из игранного мной самый ближайший аналог - Company of Heroes, правда урезанная в несколько раз и уже куда ближе к Dawn of War III.  Плюсы: - Графика атмосферна, выглядит очень даже париятно - Анимация, тут действительно всё хорошо - Разрушение построек, ну наконец-то здания разрушаются не мечами, они сжигаются  Минусы: - Геймплей, бегаем по меткам и закликиваем что просят, как мне не нравилось это в Company of Heroes, но там хотя бы другие элементы проработангы куда лучше - Стратегия, далеко не прошёл, судить сложно, но в начале её нет вообще, в стиле - против лома есть приём - лом побольше и вдвоём - Бесячий интерфейс, постоянно пытается привлечь внимание к себе, всё моргает

The Banished Vault is like 'Hey kid, wanna do some math?" and then laughs at me as I strand my exiles on the Hallowed Planet as I had the hubris to think I could inscribe our journey there.   The Banished Vault is about resource management across a solar system where there are a few things you must do, and a lot of things you really would like to be doing, but time and resources conspire to make getting through everything impossible. But that's good, because the tension in the game comes from realising you have more options than you think. Necessity breeds creativity as the most straightforward but perhaps resource intensive option gives way to clever workarounds. There's plenty of room for failure, but every mistake is a learning opportunity and the game's mechanic feel as deep as the void.

[h1] AI has been rebalnced. Dev's listen to feedback. Fairly solid game.[/h1]  It's a fairly solid concept. I dont care that the physics arent real world physics it's still fun.  Some concepts like the armor slant are great but some objects like shields feel utterly useless as all they do is block your turrets from firing and do nothing but expload when attacked. You think the shield generator would be more useful and let your turrets shoot through it but not enemy turrets or something. Really feels like a useless addition ot the base.  The AI has been reworked giving the player more of a learning experiance, Where as the "Easy" AI back at release used to feel like it was on hard or normal mode. This was patched. The Easy AI is slow, Normal AI is normal, hard is hard. Wether or not the AI still "aimbots" because well, Almost all AI is practically blind in the literal sense, I dont know. But I do know it was reworked to be less frustrating  It's overall pretty fun and a neat concept.  (if you're reading this review after the edit note that the developer response was from a pre-edit when I said the AI was abysmally bad and just absolutely ridiculous to fight)

Это одна из самых недооцененных игро-фильмов. Графика 7 из 10 , геймплей 8 из 10 , сюжет 100 из 10 . Такого отличного детектив сюжета очень редко увидешь . Начиная от  Обучения (сначала подумаешь пофиг а потом кааааак поймешь ) заканчивая финальной сценой . Моральный выбор влияет на сюжет. QTE ( ААА ПОЧЕМУ НЕ ПРОЖАЛОСЬ XXXX АААА)  огонь . И самое главное - весь этот потрясающий геймплей на движке юнити . Жестких багов которые руинят игру особо нет , бывает размытие фокусировки камеры и раза 1-2 и то в конце игры , персонажи порой скажут пару слов на английском и это не ру дубляж, это оригинал озвучка . Короче игра огонь , взял бы и за фулл прай, но за всего лишь 179 руб это вообще даром отдают .

game: 鬼谷八荒 Tale of Immortal
review: 我在第四年的时候遇到了可爱的女孩子，然后我和她聊天双修品茗让我感受到这游戏的内容和快乐。 然后我为了搜集材料去修炼攒材料准备结晶准备突破，就这样过了三年，三年后我再回头找却再也找不到她，我问朋友，她跟我说好感度只要到了一心就能在地图看到位置，然后我找了整个地图却怎么也找不到，我回到遇到她的地方去找，去拍卖会去寻找和她有关的消息，相同的姓氏我都点开一一查看，却怎么也找不到她，经历只能保存四年，我一开始还能看到她还活着年龄和我一样，直到经历没法查看了我也没找到她，我于是每年每个月都在各个地方寻找，所有的晶石都用来传送到各个城市就为了寻找她，然后我就这样找了25年，中间我什么事情都没干就一直传送，找人，传送，找人，拍卖会开始我就挨个点开看关系，只想看到哪怕她已经黑白的头像也好，哪怕看到她已经结婚我都能接受，只想有个交待，但我没有找到。 我从夜里11点开始玩玩到第二天的中午，一直重复找人传送的过程，我也不知道是为什么，但是到最后也没找到她我真的很难过，从来没有玩游戏这么难过。  此情可待成追忆，只是当时已惘然

(IT) Mi scuso di non rivolgermi all'utenza esprimendomi in inglese, ma preferisco parlare correttamente in italiano. ---- Trama: semplicemente, le basi erano buone, ma una sceneggiatura mal sviluppata rende la visione molto pesante e difficile da sostenere.  ---- Character design: come la trama, anche questo aveva delle buone basi, tuttavia la stereotipizzazione è stata portata a un livello ben più evidente, e per questo, risulta difficile empatizzare con i personaggi. A livello grafico, meh, alcuni personaggi sono ben concepiti, ma la loro realizzazione e la relativa collocazione nelle scene non è delle migliori, senza contare che nelle CGs molte posizioni sono identiche (ignoro la natura, forse economica, di questa scelta), mettendo in evidenza il poco impegno riversato in questo aspetto. Doppiaggio pressoché buono, ma poco valorizzato appunto dalla grafica.  La scena più ““memorabile”” è quando il protagonista torna da Yuki per restituirle l’orecchino che aveva smarrito, e sebbene nella scena normale (non CG) fosse assente all’orecchio destro, nella CG invece l’orecchino era presente … avrei passato per una scena di poco significato, ma inciampare su un dettaglio grafico su cui la trama stessa si sofferma … mi trovo incapace di esprimere il mio disappunto … ---- Design e ambienti: mi trovo in difficoltà ad esprimermi su questo aspetto, perché la sensazione che ho avuto (e che a tratti ha trovato conferma) è che chi si è occupato degli sfondi, si sia limitato a ricercarli in qualche libreria free-use … personalmente non ho nulla in contrario verso chi usa queste librerie, ma il modo osceno con cui il responsabile ha inserito nella medesima VN, sfondi con palesi stili diversi mi ha fatto storcere il naso non poco: la scarsità di fondi per permettersi tutti gli sfondi personalizzati è giustificabile, ma l’incuria che c’è dietro, no. Non posso negare che tra i vari sfondi, ce ne sia qualcuno ben realizzato, ma il dubbio che ho precedentemente esposto, mi impedisce di riconoscere i meriti verso chi si è occupato della grafica. ---- Colonna sonora: tracce memorabili? Oltre alla canzone (direi, piuttosto carina), non molte … per lo più le ho trovate “commerciali” o "anonime", talvolta mal inserite nel contesto (come la traccia “sensuale”, durante la sfilata delle ragazze in yukata, inserita in quei pochi secondi nel vano tentativo di creare un'atmosfera idonea). ---- Esperienza di gioco e impressioni: premetto che non ero partito con le aspettative a mille, ma man mano che procedevo, la mia esperienza si è fatta sempre più pesante: interfaccia osboleta, il gioco che talvolta crashava quando aprivo la sezione dei salvataggi, i vari elementi sopra menzionati, alcune parti non tradotte in inglese, etc. …  Sinceramente, sarei stato comprensivo se si fosse trattato di un titolo “in fase di sviluppo” ad accesso anticipato (Early access), ma qui si ha un prodotto “finito” (probabilmente doveva essere una VN a più route, ma la ragione per cui si sono fermati ad una sola, rimane un mistero …) e messo in vendita, per una cifra che non ritengo nemmeno opportuna (per fortuna, l’ho pagato a prezzo ridotto grazie ad un coupon). La parte, a mio avviso, peggiore, è stata quella di visitare la home page del team di sviluppo, e non vedere questo titolo apparire tra i loro prodotti: come posso portare rispetto verso un’opera che persino gli stessi autori hanno deciso di celare, e che per di più, viene venduta a un prezzo non idoneo per i suoi contenuti? ---- Quindi, per tutti i motivi sopra menzionati, sconsiglio vivamente di giocare questo titolo, se non per mera curiosità, e a prezzo ridotto.

약 45~50시간이면 엔딩 봄 (스포 없는 리뷰)  -장점 1. 화려한 연출과 타격감으로 전투가 지겹지 않음 딸피 처리 시 동료와 함께 연계하는 부스트 스트라이크, 비오의 등등 연출이 화려해서 보는 맛이 훌륭함  2. 동료들의 캐미가 돋보임 서브퀘나 전투 도중 나오는 잡담들, 그리고 스킷에서 동료들과의 캐미가 정말 잘 어울림 각자 뚜렷한 성격이 있어서 캐릭터 덕질하기 좋음  3. 화려한 컷신들 스토리 진행 도중 등장하는 3d 컷신들은 바지에 오줌 지릴정도로 훌륭하고 화려함. 애니 컷신은 작붕이다 뭐다 말이 많은데 난 괜찮았음  4. 재미있는 서브퀘들  무지성 "뭐 때문에 힘드니깐 몇 마리 잡아와라" 이런 서브퀘들이 아님 서브퀘들 받을때, 또 클리어 할 때 동료들의 잡담듣고 있으면 너무 재미있음  -단점  1. 흡입력이 좋았던 1부에 비해 2부 스토리가 늘어짐  스토리 작가가 바뀐건가 싶을 정도로 2부 스토리가 1부와는 달리 너무 늘어짐 방대한 세계관과 떡밥을 실수로 흘리고 황급히 주워담으려는듯 보였음 스토리에 대해 설명해주고 싶은 마음은 알겠으나 2부 시작하자마자 무지성 스킷 난무로 게임의 집중력이 저하됨  2. 2부 최종장 던전 피돼지들의 뇌절, 그리고 던전 길이  2부 후반부부터 갑자기 피돼지 슈퍼아머 둘둘한 중형몹들이랑 연속적으로 싸워야 함 콤보 쌓는 재미로 하던 게임이 때려도 움찔거리지도 않는 중형몹들의 등장으로 무지성 피하기-공격 게임이 되어버림 진짜 하루 웬종일 줘패야 한마리 죽임.  게다가 최종장 던전은 길이도 존나게 긴데 필연적으로 이 피돼지들과 싸워야 하는 구간이 너무나도 많음 전투 재미있게 하다가 처음으로 난이도 최하로 낮추고 함   (종합)  보는 맛과 써는 맛을 좋아하고 세계관을 천천히 음미하는 유저에게 추천  단순히 액션 겜만 찾아왔고 글, 스토리 읽는거 싫어하는 사람에겐 비추천  전자에겐 정가주고 사도 좋고 후자는 세일 때 사는걸 추천

The standard. This is how open world fantasy is done. Stand up and take notice.

[h1]An ocean of sand[/h1]  It's finally here. Journey can be considered Thatgamecompany's Magnum Opus, not only it's the last game of the PS3 trilogy and the most impressive one in all possible ways but it's also a very influential game for the industry since it came out in 2012, it's a very special moment then so let's review it, shall we?   We wake up in the middle of the desert, everything is sand but you can see three stones on the horizon and a huge light in the sky that comes from the other side of the dune, you star walking until you reach the highest point and there it is, the mountain, this is the starting point of your journey through the remains of an ancient civilization now long gone.  The story won't be told to us directly, we must find out what happened and what's happening to us thanks to the old marks left on the different sections of the game, hidden and directly faced to you the story will slowly be revealed to us through the very own environment. The structures, every element is important to transmit Information about what happened and the feeling of a forgotten and abandoned place that nature has reclaimed.  You won't have to face this journey alone as you will encounter random users in your walkthrough, you won't be able to write or speak but you will be able to communicate with them thanks to the tones you generate, help yourselves mutually, let the game guide you and your companions.  There's so little I can add to what it has been already said about the technical aspects of this game, visually splendid, the sand effect is gorgeous and even more impressive if we take into consideration that this game came out in 2012, OST is STUNNING, the right tracks at the right moments, beautiful. Length is also a good factor, game will take around an hour and a half or two hours to complete, it's short but very intense.  PC ports works really well, is not very demanding and performance is really good, high framerate makes this game go so smoothly that makes a huge difference, however, both PS4 and PC have a different effect for the sand and even tho is not very noticeable or it won't be at all if you didn't play the original, you might see something different the first time you start playing this versions, it doesn't have any effect on the experience.  In conclusion, Journey is a masterpiece that helped and contributed numberless times to the modern video-game scene thanks to it's unique design and style, it's short but it doesn't need more than 2 hours to make you fall in love with it, a journey through the sands and remains of a forgotten civilization that fell a long time ago but this journey is one that is more enjoyable when you have a partner at your side. I absolutely recommend this game and I really hope you can appreciate how stunning this game truly is.  Journey is on PC, you have no excuse now.

Call of Cthulhu is really all about the story. There really isn't much gameplay other than walking around to explore and talk to people/interact with objects. There are only a couple of combat and stealth sections throughout the entire game and they're very basic yet clunky. I see a lot of reviews saying the combat ruined the game but there's probably 5-10 minutes of combat in the entire game and they come towards the end of the game, it's not like the game is focused on the combat by any means.  It's all about the story. It's a really interesting psychological horror game without jump scares. I think there was one jump scare throughout the game and it really caught me off guard because I just accepted that it didn't have jump scares. The story's really interesting though as are all the characters. It kept me wanting to play the next chapter to see what happens next. It's rather short, I finished it at about 6 hours. If you're in the mood for a scary game, give it a go.

The only way to beat the NSA at their own game... is to play their own game.  Orwell's a fun journey inside national surveillance, and though it's obviously a bit campy, most of the picture it paints is eerily similar to the real world we live in. The music's super cool. The thematic elements are edgy but accurate. Also, it's 3-ish hours long (but has a lot of different endings for replayability). On a related note, this game dunks hard on Antifa (though I assume the devs will deny it), so, yeah, give it a buy if you want those pansies to get their comeuppance.

I really tried to like this game. I liked the start in the house, seemed like exactly the kind of trippy and unusual game I would enjoy. The whole 'press E' in the Windmill level just annoyed me too much. I can't get passed that point because having to repeat the exact same bit over and over because I put a foot wrong and it gets to frustrating and just boring. That part of the game just felt very "trial and error" and really not needed. I know It's a puzzle game but that part is just really not fun. It's such a shame because I feel like this has potential but it's ruined for me by that part. I gave the level 3 chances, about a week apart but I like it less each time. I really hope a future update for the game will remove E-mashing or at least give you more than a second of stepping off the path before getting thrown back to the start. I've not given up hope yet and if I see an update for the game, I will try playing again.

Alternatively, I used "Parsec gaming" for my bf to stream onto my computer and play the game "locally" with me: I had to connect two X-box controllers and let him use the keyboard while I played on a controller to make it work as of today fyi if that tip helps anyone!

Compared to the previous game, it should be noted that new content has been added to the game that makes it special, for example, new movement options have been added not only for the player but also when there is interaction with objects, in addition they have upgraded the quality of the game's graphics and its visual appearance, the shooting mechanics and the concept of the difficulty levels also was changed . All this is nice and useful for the game, but there are also a lot of disadvantages to this game, especially compared to the previous game (maybe because it's the beta, but still). I encountered a lot of bugs when creating a lobby with friends, the optimization does not match the level of the new quality of the graphics, and interaction with the bots became even worse than the previous game, the planning room for the robbery was removed from the game which in my opinion was one of the most important parts of the game, And in addition, on the normal difficulty level, all types of enemies in the game are summoned. In conclusion there should be a lot of work done before releasing the game especially with the optimization so the game at least can feel better and smooth.

this has become one of my favourite games of all time. the comedic moments are funny, the combat is thoughtful and high paced and the characters are understandable and likeable.  i do have some problems: 1.the story while working well in its length might've been better if it was a bit longer in addition to the fact that there isn't any real reason to get 100% spirit fulfilment besides the obvious  2.the combat can be easily exploited, even on normal mode and all it takes to beat every enemy in the game is one or two hits after maxing out attack 3.there isn't any consequences to being defeated (with the exception of the final boss) so there's no real reason to bother taking any fight (except the final one) seriously, in addition to being able to defeat any enemy in (at most) two hits 4.the ending that you get if you don't beat the final boss is too heavy and depressing and would've been less shocking and jarring if the scene of the stones wasn't there  otherwise, its an amazing that i recommend that you should play if you haven't already.

Amazing world sim that feels somehow more fluid and enabling than Rimworld. You start off with a decent colonist (i. e. dwarf) count so that there is none of the sluggish starting phase as in the default 3 colonists setting of Rimworld. Also the work tends to be more smoothly automated once you get to use work orders, you can automate most anything but still be flexible with one-time orders. The fact that you have dozens of layers means you can expand quickly (albeit vertically) and will not run into space issues any time soon. (compared to Rimworld in a stony region)  For me it's definitely the better game (although I really like Rimworld) just for the bottomless freedom you have. The simple fact of quick expansion with a lot more characters means you are not constantly hamstrung / bottlenecked by bad traits, RNG luck on abilities etc.  However, with just some hours in I cannot yet say if there is sufficient 'external' motivation from enemies to make the game feel challenging. Where I am right now it's mostly about satisfying the needs of your dwarves. And in any case, you can always play with the settings when creating a new map and make it as difficult as you like.  I can fully recommend it.

game: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review: Não é a toa que QUASE ganhou o GOTY de 2008. Fallout 3 conseguiu a façanha de ser uma game pós apocalíptico extremamente imersivo e abocanhar uma grande quantidade de fãs ( eu me inclui na lista).  Vamos começar pela história, que realmente é ótima e tem uma ligação com os games anteriores ( mesmo que rasa). Resumindo bem, o mundo entrou em uma guerra nuclear e as pessoas se abrigaram dentro de abrigos nucleares construídos pela empresa Vault-tec, justamente para evitar a extinção da humanidade na guerra. Você é um(a) jovem que cresceu dentro de um abrigo nuclear e sua mãe morre logo no parto, fazendo ele abandonar seu trabalho temporariamente para cuidar de você. Você cresce dentro do vault, aprende sobre a Vault-tec e uma base de como é o universo da saga, aprendendo mecânicas básicas e avançadas logo no início. Em um belo dia, seu pai some e todo mundo quer saber o que aconteceu, ou seja, muitos querem a sua cabeça ali (pois acreditam que você seja o culpado), então você precisa sair do Vault para não ser morto e explorar, por livre e espontânea pressão, o mundo pós apocalíptico. Nota: Muitos moradores dos vaults tem um medo enorme de sair para fora, pois os perigos são imensos em um mundo basicamente sem lei. Isso que eu contei não é nem 1% da história.... o game tem uma lore muito boa mesmo.   -Mecânica: até que é jogável e possui um nível de dificuldade intermediário, é só você não querer matar um deathclaw ou giant radscorpion no level 5 que você vai se dar bem. O game tem uma movimentação meio robótica e precária, mas ele compensa com outras coisas, como o sistema VATS e até com uma mecânica de XP, que torna o game com uma cara bem RPG. O game é meio complexo pelo excesso de liberdade que você tem, ou seja, você é jogado em uma mapa, tem missões primárias e secundárias, mas você pode optar por explorar o mundo antes, porém como você é level baixo, provavelmente vai sofrer bastante para vários inimigos.   -Exploração: realmente é algo que eu AMEI e AMO ainda em toda a saga, você é livre para ir onde quiser, sem restrições ou perrengues. A liberdade é total e você pode explorar bastante os lugares.  Pontos negativos:  - Polimento gráfico: não que o gráfico seja feio, mas faltou bastante polimento por parte da empresa, onde vemos muitos ambientes e itens bem quadriculados e mal feitos. No macro até que fallout é bonitinho, mas no micro é bem feio.   -Polimento de movimentação: Realmente poderiam melhorar a fluidez do personagem em andar, porque ele é bem robótico e os inimigos também. Poderiam ter acrescentado mais detalhes.  -Incompatibilidade com windows mais recentes: nos windows mais crescentes sempre acontecem alguns crashes bem chatinhos, que até hoje não foram resolvidos aparentemente.   Resumo geral: O game, mesmo não tendo nada de inovador, tem uma história ótima, uma progressão de dificuldade boa ( bem melhor que a de the witcher: enhanced edition) e também um sistema de karma muito bem trabalhado, com diálogos e caminhas muito variados. É um jogaço para amantes deste estilo.
